title: Question 73

children: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for follow-up of a gastric ulcer. He is asymptomatic. Upper endoscopy performed 4 weeks ago revealed a 1-cm, clean-based, cratered ulcer in the gastric antrum. Biopsy specimens from the ulcer margin were negative for malignancy. Random biopsy specimens from the stomach were negative for
. He has discontinued daily ibuprofen, previously used for osteoarthritis of the knees. Current medications are acetaminophen and omeprazole.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Endoscopy after 8 weeks of proton pump inhibitor therapy
Endoscopy after 12 weeks of proton pump inhibitor therapy

children: Routine repeat upper endoscopy for gastric ulcer is not recommended.

Repeat upper endoscopy for gastric ulcer is reasonable for ulcers that appear suspicious for malignancy, ulcers that were not biopsied originally, ulcers with an unclear cause, or continued symptoms despite adequate therapy.
The most appropriate next step in management is no further surveillanceâ€”no follow-up endoscopy is needed (

). Surveillance endoscopy is based on the concern that some gastric cancers present as gastric ulcers that initially appear endoscopically and histologically benign. However, this rationale is of limited clinical use and is not cost-effective. As such, no U.S. or Canadian gastroenterology society has recommended routine surveillance for gastric ulcers. Instead, the decision to perform surveillance endoscopy for a gastric ulcer should be individualized. Surveillance with endoscopy is not necessary in patients with a low risk for gastric cancer, such as this patient, who was taking an NSAID and had endoscopic findings suggesting a typical NSAID-associated gastric ulcer, unremarkable biopsy specimens from the ulcer, and symptom resolution with appropriate medical therapy.

Surveillance endoscopy may be considered in gastric ulcers that appear suspicious for malignancy, ulcers that were not biopsied at the time of index endoscopy, or ulcers with an unclear cause. Features of the ulcer that raise suspicion for malignancy include a dirty ulcer base, a raised ulcer border, and/or irregular ulcer margins. Ulcers larger than 3 cm should also be followed endoscopically given their increased risk for complications, including rebleeding, penetration, and/or perforation. Refractory ulcers (those failing to heal despite 8-12 weeks of antisecretory therapy) should be considered for surveillance endoscopy (
) until healing is documented or until the cause is defined, such as surreptitious NSAID use, high-gastrin states, or ischemia.

references: Banerjee S, Cash BD, Dominitz JA, et al; ASGE Standards of Practice Committee. The role of endoscopy in the management of patients with peptic ulcer disease. Gastrointest Endosc. 2010;71:663-8.
